; very recently, a just published volume collects various essays about this same topic just about the Late Antique, Medieval (both Christian and Isla

tween our two projects continued: now we are able to offer to EDB users to view on the updated map of the catacomb of Domitilla the distribution of the inscriptions still
in the four levels of the subterranean cemetery

Materials and shape of the written objects
, before the inscribed texts. Because now we can do it, we have to display to
users of our projects the real communicative power of the inscriptions, that assume much more meaningfulness when we can see them than when we can read their

texts in a library. By pictures and 3D rendering of the places where the epigraphs were arranged we should be able also to provide virtual images of inscriptions - also lost or incomplete - conceived to be seen and read exactly there. An effective example can be the dedication by pope Damasus (366-384) to the martyr
in the catacomb of Praetextatus on the via Appia
Rome, catacomb of Praetextatus. Damasus‚Äô dedicatory inscription
Photo: PCAS; 3D rendering: G. De Felice
The bishop of Rome reaches his aim to capture the gaze also of

faithfuls by placing a very large slab of white marble over the tomb of the martyr, well-lighted by a skylight made on purpose, in strong contrast to the darkness of the neighbouring galleries of the subterranean cemetery.
Also the text is aimed at the same goal: the dedication is brief and si
ple, inscribed using a special writing, very carefully carved by using a font specially elaborated for Damasus' inscriptions by the fashionable designer
. The contrast with the common inscriptions in the catacombs,
made by reused marble pieces or bricks, and very often (not always!) written with rough letters, is impressive. The bishop's interve
tion is more meaningfully revealed to all by the visual features of his i

This notion about written monuments is more and more diffused in Western Early Middle Ages and also in Byzantium: one has no need to read, to perceive the actual and effective messages displayed by inscriptions placed within the fabric of the walls of Byzantine cities, such as Constant
Thessaloniki, city walls. Inscriptions in the masonry of a tower near Eptapyrgion (photo: A. E. Felle).
There, the inscriptions are not carved in marble slabs or stone blocks, but they are realized with the same materials of the walls: simple bricks, but di
visible also from afar. The inscriptions explain the walls; the walls speak its
scriptions, that are in different cases rich of abbreviations, closed to the rea
ing but open to the sight: writing appears
significant. In my opinion, this notion is clearly demonstrated by the unnecessary captions in the icons and in the images of martyrs
, where - on closer view - the inscriptions are completely useless
if we continue to consider them only as texts to be read.
pse mosaic with the image of the martyr
Indeed - more over in Late Antiquity and Middle Ages - readability of the texts is not the main property of inscriptions: rather, the main condition appears their
. An incisive example can be offered by the Christian inscriptions bearing biblical quotations
n the middle of the bronze plating of the marble lintel over the Great Door of the Royal Gates
Haghia Sophia in Constantinople, an empty throne is occupied by an open
from the founding period of the church"
is inscribed a focused - but barely readable - quot
tion from John 10, verses 7 and 9, where Jesus indicates himself as
. (Therefore Jesus said again,¬†‚ÄòVery truly I tell you, I am the gate for the sheep);

he archeological context and the mirate positioning make tangible
the sacred words; and the real presence (not
the readability) of the sacred words give pr
Royal Gates of the Great Church of Constantinople
Scarce or null readability does not imply low quality of the appearance of

: rather, the writing appears intrinsecally meaningful such as visual element of the equipment of a simple or rich funerary monument or of a cultual building. Then, we have to face the issue of the description of the writing
we are still waiting for a shared and controlled vocabulary of paleographical defin
to perceive and to understand its non-verbal signif
cance: by its disposition, direction, shape. The notion of the inscriptions in the Islamic world, where often the letters are also - and maybe firstly - i
ages (they are used as decorative friezes, architectural ornaments, figures
and their clearity and readability are not considered as necessary, can help us to evocate this feature of
. Granada, Alhambra. An example of the writing as decorative frieze and architectural ornaments (Photo: A. E. Felle)
The ancient inscriptions actually belong to civilizations where the liter
cy - with very few exception - was very far from our standard: to see an i
scription with the same point of view of the most part of the citizens in R
man Empire - and mostly in Late Antiquity - we have to become, in some way, illiterate.
In conclusion: we have to consider in digital descriptions of the inscri

tions some their "visual features" that in our projects - first of all in EDB, of course - are not too considered, although they are very significant. We need, about encoding these non-verbal features, the same positive results that by Epidoc we reached
in encoding the texts: a hard challenge.
